values.alignmentText: Glaciers, fjords, and low pollution create spectacular nature escapes, even if gear and careful planning are needed for the kids.
Arctic warming is racing ahead of global averages, threatening permafrost, fisheries, and coastal settlements the family would rely on.
Polar night stretches for months and short summers stay chilly, far from the mild year-round climate we want.
With minimal industry and ocean winds, air stays crisp except for occasional wood-stove smoke in winter.
Major quakes or storms are rare, yet warming-driven landslides and coastal erosion add nontrivial safety planning.
Spring hovers below freezing until May, so playground time still needs snow gear.
Summer highs around 10–12°C (50–54°F) stay brisk for outdoor play despite the long daylight.
Autumn rapidly slides back to freezing with early snowfall and storms shortening daylight.
Winter brings -20°C (-4°F) cold snaps and weeks without sun, a poor fit for Sarah’s low-stress climate goals.
Shorelines are icy and rugged, so there’s no family-friendly beach culture.
Sea temperatures rarely top 5°C (41°F), making swimming unsafe without drysuits.
Towering icebergs, northern lights, and fjords provide awe-inspiring backdrops for family adventures.
There’s no statutory minimum; union contracts pay well on paper but disappear quickly under Greenland’s extreme living costs.
Local tech hiring is sparse, so sustaining US-level income would depend on remote contracts.
Government IT teams are tiny, leaving .NET specialists reliant on remote-first roles.
No meaningful Ruby market exists, so any work would have to stay with international clients.
Few employers recruit abroad, and sponsorship still routes through Denmark’s quotas.
GDP hinges on fisheries and Danish block grants, leaving little resilience for entrepreneurs.
Internet has improved but long-haul links stay latency-heavy, so Trey would need backup connectivity.
Nordic norms keep overtime rare and leave time for family, even in small public-sector offices.
Standard workweek near 40 hours; overtime uncommon.
Five weeks of statutory leave mirror Denmark, giving space for long trips back to the States.
Most teams take the full allowance, though small staffs sometimes stagger time off to keep services running.
Short commutes and tight-knit towns offer the slower daily rhythm Sarah craves.
Schools run roughly 8–14h and offices finish by 16h, but limited after-school care means parents juggle shifts.
Weekends revolve around outdoor excursions and community events, yet weather can cancel plans last-minute.
Close-knit towns foster community ties yet can feel isolating for newcomers.
Traditional social norms leave little open acceptance for non-monogamous relationships.
Child independence and resilience are valued due to harsh conditions.
Low traffic and small size are safe for kids but amenities are sparse.
Public schools operate in Greenlandic and Danish with limited advanced courses.
Daycare exists in larger towns yet slots are limited and costs high.
Municipal subsidies reduce fees for resident families.
Foreign residents may access services but language and availability pose hurdles.
Free compulsory schooling through grade 10, though quality varies by town.
Access similar for resident foreigners but remote locales limit choices.
Virtually no private or international schools available.
Nordic-style benefits include parental leave and child allowances.
Eligibility depends on residence status and can require navigation of Danish rules.
Few local programs; many students study in Denmark with support.
Foreigners face limited local options and may need to relocate for university.
Community life retains some traditional gender divisions.
Small population offers limited visibility and support for gender-nonconforming individuals.
Legally aligned with Denmark, providing strong gender equality protections.
Practical clothing and roles shaped by climate; modest fashion expectations.
Hunting and manual skills are esteemed, reinforcing traditional masculinity.
Blend of Inuit and Danish cultures amid Arctic landscapes offers a unique experience.
Greenlandic and Danish dominate daily life; English helps with youth and tourism but isn’t reliable for bureaucracy.
Politics lean social-democratic, though some social issues track more traditional Inuit and Danish norms.
Economic model mixes market activity with significant public ownership.
Lutheran heritage remains but secular lifestyles are common.
Public discourse is reserved; sex education follows Danish standards.
Legal protections follow Denmark, but tiny communities mean limited queer visibility and peer support.
Tight-knit towns foster mutual aid but privacy can be scarce.
Strong sense of indigenous identity and autonomy aspirations.
Close ties with Denmark and interest in Arctic cooperation.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as remote yet strategically important; generally positive relations.
Small bar scene centered in Nuuk; nightlife options are limited.
Functional outerwear dominates; little emphasis on global trends.
Practical attire prioritizes warmth over style.
Hunting, fishing, and sledding are popular pastimes.
Small hobby groups may exist but limited by population size.
Occasional concerts and festivals, yet overall scene is modest.
Few organized groups; expats often rely on online networks.
Outstanding access to wilderness right outside town boundaries.
A home-rule parliament under Denmark keeps democratic institutions transparent and accountable.
Religion plays minimal role in policy decisions.
Unionization and labor protections mirror Danish standards.
Social-democratic governance emphasizes welfare and regional autonomy.
Strong links to Danish rule-of-law and an active press make backsliding unlikely despite the small media market.
Mixed economy with significant public sector and subsidies.
Political stability is strong though economic shifts could impact it.
Media landscape is small but generally free of heavy propaganda.
Occasional emphasis on cultural pride and autonomy aspirations.
Universal healthcare, subsidized childcare, and education support mirror Nordic welfare priorities.
Residents trust core services but question how efficiently Nuuk manages remote settlements.
Transparency is generally good, though small-town hiring can feel insider-based.
Issues mostly involve patronage or family ties rather than large-scale graft.
Housing shortages and high construction costs, especially in Nuuk.
Violent crime is rare, yet alcohol-related domestic incidents mean we’d need robust community support networks.
Primary care is universal, but serious cases require medevac to Denmark, adding travel stress.
Resident permits grant access, though Danish referrals and language gaps add friction.
Municipal daycares exist but waitlists and staffing shortages are common in Nuuk.
Nuclear families are standard with strong state support.
Outcomes trail Danish averages, so the boys would likely need supplemental tutoring or boarding options later on.
Town buses cover short hops, yet there are no intercity roads—travel between communities needs flights or ferries.
A mixed economy balances public control with small private firms, but scale is limited.
Payroll tax collected via Danish-style PAYE system.
High Nordic tax burden could reach 40%+, reducing disposable income.
Modern banking tied to Danish systems with online services available.
Almost everything is imported, so groceries and gear cost well above Danish levels.
State pension and supplements provide a stable retirement framework.
Eligibility depends on contribution history and residency length.
Residence permits flow through Danish immigration, with tight quotas and case-by-case approvals.
Locals are friendly yet protective of community resources, so integration takes time.
Temporary permits require renewal and proof of employment; permanent residency demands long stays and language.
Naturalization follows Denmark’s 9+ year timeline plus Danish-language exams.
Dependents qualify for permits, but housing and school placement must be secured in advance.
Applications can stretch past six months and require travel to Danish consulates.
Losing the sponsoring job or failing Danish paperwork can quickly end the stay.
Denmark permits dual nationality, enabling retention of US passports.
Remote logistics, medevac travel, and language barriers mean the family would need contingency plans.
No local studios exist, so Trey would have to build everything remotely.

As noted in Game Dev Work Prospects, No local studios exist, so Trey would have to build everything remotely. Hiring velocity at established studios in Greenland is exceptionally slow, with roles frequently on hold or reliant on remote talent.

Compensation lags global peers, pushing candidates to consider remote packages or supplemental income. When opportunities surface in Greenland, established studios benchmark offers against peers across the ecosystem.
Established studios in Greenland rely on English for cross-border collaboration, while local-language fluency remains important for community, compliance, and platform partnerships.
Remote expectations at established studios in Greenland require on-site presence, with remote collaboration rarely supported.
There are no established Greenlandic studios to network with.
Occasional school workshops happen, but most collaboration would remain online.
Funding is scarce beyond small cultural grants, and the local market is tiny.

Startup founders report that Funding is scarce beyond small cultural grants, and the local market is tiny. Hiring velocity at early-stage studios in Greenland is exceptionally slow, with roles frequently on hold or reliant on remote talent.
Compensation lags global peers, pushing candidates to consider remote packages or supplemental income. Early teams in Greenland balance cash and equity to stay competitive while managing runway.
Founding teams in Greenland lean on English for investor and platform communication, while local-language fluency helps with hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Remote expectations among startups in Greenland require on-site presence, with remote collaboration rarely supported.
Nuuk has reliable power and broadband, yet settlements rely on diesel and limited transport links.
Chronic life-threatening swings and infrastructure strain make the family question long-term viability without major resiliency investments.
Months of oppressive darkness or bright nights disrupt sleep cycles and make remote work or study harder to sustain.
Comfortable days are infrequent; we constantly monitor forecasts to grab the odd mild afternoon.
Families regularly compromise on safety or overcrowd to stay housed; civic support is patchy.
Lifestyle feels brittle; one unexpected expense forces significant cutbacks or debt.
Affluent families struggle to find peer communities or trusted providers locally.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Spacious rentals are rare; we likely settle for smaller homes or relocate to a different metro.
Community living is rare and often under-resourced, requiring significant personal effort to sustain.
Interactions feel transactional; expect friendly acquaintances but limited favors or shared childcare.
Negative media framing and policy tightenings create a defensive posture for newcomers.
White migrants are linked to gentrification or colonial histories, prompting cool interactions.
Service norms are pragmatic; smiles and chit-chat are rare outside personal networks.
Depth is limited—most locals keep emotional distance except with lifelong friends.
Touchy or crowded norms are common and require constant boundary setting.
Politeness norms favor indirect communication; being candid sometimes backfires.
Looking impeccable is expected daily, creating stress for a low-maintenance family.
Body shaming is common and influences opportunities or friendships.
Designer or curated looks are assumed, pressuring constant wardrobe investment.
Consent education is weak; unwanted advances occur regularly.
Rigid gender expectations create discomfort for progressive or queer expressions.
Negative narratives dominate; openness threatens custody, employment, or housing. non-monogamy acceptance.
Conservative norms dominate; promiscuity is equated with poor character.
Disclosure triggers backlash or official scrutiny.
Physical proximity is unavoidable in many settings with limited accommodations.
Permissive laws and visible ownership prompt caution in public spaces.
Enforcement leans punitive; we monitor rules closely to avoid harsh consequences.
Enforcement feels unpredictable with regular raids or public shaming campaigns.
Mass violence risk is an ongoing topic; we regularly rehearse safety plans.
Overcrowding or low wages appear in investigative reports, raising ethical concerns.
Pedestrian deaths or injuries are common; car dominance limits independence.
Healthy living requires self-direction; fast food and sedentary habits dominate social life.
Healthy choices are overshadowed by processed fare in most neighborhoods.
Produce quality or range is inconsistent; international cuisine is niche.
Prevalence is high with long waits and patchy insurance coverage.
Higher obesity prevalence indicates limited access to healthy routines in some areas.
Slightly elevated incidence prompts routine checkups and monitoring.
Single-industry dominance makes downturns painful and long-lasting.
